brief_description: Determining the extent to which original antigenic sin is induced by variant influenza viruses by using two related strains of influenza
brief_title: Original Antigenic Sin Responses to Influenza Viruses
condition_studied: tested the induction of original antigenic sin in mice using two H1N1 influenza virus strains A/PR/8/34 (PR8) and A/FM/1/47 (FM1)
description: Determining the extent to which original antigenic sin is induced by variant influenza viruses by using two related strains of influenza
endpoints: Showing that sequential infection of mice with two live influenza virus strains leads to almost exclusive Ab responses to the first viral strain, suggesting that original antigenic sin could be a potential strategy by which variant influenza viruses subvert the immune system
hypothesis: Show that original antigenic sin leads to a significant decrease in development of protective immunity and recall responses to the second virus
objectives: Show that sequential infection of mice with two live influenza virus strains leads toalmost exclusive Ab responses to the first viral strain, suggesting that original antigenic sin could be a potential strategy by which variant influenza viruses subvert the immune system
official_title: Original Antigenic Sin Responses to Influenza Viruses
